definitions.definition: a small area on a surface having a different color from its surroundings, typically one caused by accident or damage.
examples: the blow left a red mark down one side of her face
synonyms: discoloration; birthmark; informalsplotch; technicalstigma "a dirty mark"

definitions.definition: a spot, area, or feature on a person's or animal's body by which they may be identified or recognized.
examples: he was five feet nine, with no distinguishing marks

definitions.definition: a line, figure, or symbol made as an indication or record of something.
examples: symbol, sign, character; Morediacritic "a punctuation mark"logo, seal, stamp, imprint, symbol, emblem, device, insignia, badge, brand, trademark, monogram, hallmark, logotype, watermark "books bearing the mark of a well-known bookseller"Morediacritic a punctuation marklogo, seal, stamp, imprint, symbol, emblem, device, insignia, badge, brand, trademark, monogram, hallmark, logotype, watermark books bearing the mark of a well-known bookseller

definitions.definition: a written symbol made on a document in place of a signature by someone who cannot write.
examples: impression, imprint, traces; Moreeffect, impact, influence "the war left its mark on him"Moreeffect, impact, influence the war left its mark on him

definitions.definition: a level or stage that is considered significant.
examples: unemployment had passed the two million mark
synonyms: degree "unemployment passed the three million mark"

definitions.definition: a sign or indication of a quality or feeling.
examples: the flag was at half-mast as a mark of respect
synonyms: indicator "the mark of a civilized society"

definitions.definition: a characteristic property or feature.
examples: it is the mark of a civilized society to treat its elderly members well

definitions.definition: a competitor's starting point in a race.
a piece of material or a knot used to indicate a depth on a sounding line.
one of two possible states of a signal in certain systems.
a point awarded for a correct answer or for proficiency in an examination or competition.
examples: many candidates lose marks because they don't read the questions carefully

definitions.definition: a figure or letter representing the total correct answers in an examination and signifying a person's score.
examples: the highest mark was 98 percent
synonyms: percentage "he got good marks for math"

definitions.definition: (especially in track and field) a time or distance achieved by a competitor, especially one which represents a record or personal best.
(followed by a numeral) a particular model or type of a vehicle, machine, or device.
examples: a Mark 10 Jaguar

definitions.definition: a target.
examples: few bullets could have missed their mark

definitions.definition: a person who is easily deceived or taken advantage of.
examples: they figure I'm an easy mark

definitions.definition: make (a visible impression or stain) on.
examples: he fingered the photograph gently, careful not to mark it
synonyms: bruise; informalsplotch; literarysmirch "be careful not to mark the paintwork"

definitions.definition: become stained.
examples: it is made from a sort of woven surface which doesn't mark or tear

definitions.definition: write a word or symbol on (an object), typically for identification.
examples: she marked all her possessions with her name

definitions.definition: write (a word or figure) on an object.
examples: she marked the date down on a card

definitions.definition: put a line by or through something written or printed on paper to indicate that it has passed or been dealt with.
examples: he marked off their names in a ledger

definitions.definition: show the position of.
examples: the top of the pass marks the border between Alaska and the Yukon

definitions.definition: separate or delineate (a particular section or area of something).
examples: you need to mark out the part of the garden where the sun lingers longest

definitions.definition: (of a particular quality or feature) separate or distinguish (someone or something) from other people or things.
examples: his sword marked him out as an officer

definitions.definition: select or destine someone for (a particular role or condition).
examples: the solicitor general marked him out for government office

definitions.definition: judge someone to be (a particular type or class of person).
examples: she had marked him down as a liberal

definitions.definition: acknowledge, honor, or celebrate (an important event or occasion) with a particular action.
examples: to mark its fiftieth anniversary, the group held a fashion show
synonyms: memorialize "a festival to mark the town's 200th anniversary"

definitions.definition: be an indication of (a significant occasion, stage, or development).
examples: the move to the new Globe theatre marked a new phase in Shakespeare’s writing career
synonyms: herald "the incidents marked a new phase in their campaign"

definitions.definition: characterize as having a particular quality or feature.
examples: the reaction to these developments has been marked by a note of hysteria
synonyms: stamp "his style is marked by simplicity and concision"

definitions.definition: (of a clock or watch) show (a certain time).
examples: his watch marked five past eight

definitions.definition: (of a teacher or examiner) assess the standard of (a piece of written work) by assigning points for proficiency or correct answers.
examples: the teachers are given adequate time to mark term papers
synonyms: correct "I have a pile of essays to mark"

definitions.definition: reduce the number of marks awarded to a student, candidate, or their work.
examples: I was marked down for having skipped the last essay question

definitions.definition: notice or pay careful attention to.
examples: he'll leave you, you mark my words!

definitions.definition: (of a player in a team game) stay close to (a particular opponent) in order to prevent them getting or passing the ball.
the basic monetary unit of Germany (until the introduction of the euro), equal to 100 pfennigs; a Deutschmark or, formerly, an Ostmark.
a former English and Scottish money of account, equal to thirteen shillings and four pence in the currency of the day.
a denomination of weight for gold and silver, formerly used throughout western Europe and typically equal to 8 ounces (226.8 grams).
